turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: You press on their view?

turn.speaker: charles_l_gilmore
turn.label: Mr. Charles L. Gilmore
turn.text: Yes, but we can't the press against the Government, Your Honor.
They didn't just --

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: charles_l_gilmore
turn.label: Mr. Charles L. Gilmore
turn.text: -- don't do anything.
We can't take adverse proceedings against the Government.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: When were these proceedings first started, that -- with relation to the condemnation proceedings?

turn.speaker: charles_l_gilmore
turn.label: Mr. Charles L. Gilmore
turn.text: It first started by a letter of June 5th, 1957 from the Solicitor from the Department of Interior directed to the Attorney General, requesting him to institute proceedings for condemnation of these lands.
Now, I'm following at -- that on 24th day of June 1957, the instant condemnation suit was filed in the District Court of Sacramento.
That's on one of the files, Your Honor, as I said before but --

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: charles_l_gilmore
turn.label: Mr. Charles L. Gilmore
turn.text: -- since -- at that day on that 24th day of June, the writ of possession was issued, the declaration of taking was filed and we have been out of possession since the 24th day of June, 1957.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: But what I was trying to get at, Mr. Gilmore was when was your proceeding before the Bureau of Land Management started?

turn.speaker: charles_l_gilmore
turn.label: Mr. Charles L. Gilmore
turn.text: I don't have the date, Your Honor, but it was --

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Well (Voice Overlap) --

turn.speaker: charles_l_gilmore
turn.label: Mr. Charles L. Gilmore
turn.text: -- preceding then, it was --

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: How long?

turn.speaker: charles_l_gilmore
turn.label: Mr. Charles L. Gilmore
turn.text: Oh, I don't know.
I think it must have been a year, a year-and-half or something.
I'm not sure (Voice Overlap) --

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Before 1957?

turn.speaker: charles_l_gilmore
turn.label: Mr. Charles L. Gilmore
turn.text: I didn't start those proceedings.
Another attorney did and he withdrew from the case.
So I have -- have had little to do with that because this matter came on and I had to take up this proceeding.
This was the pressing one.
We were faced with adverse proceedings.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: Now, those proceedings, as I understand it, sought the issuance of a patent, is that it?

turn.speaker: charles_l_gilmore
turn.label: Mr. Charles L. Gilmore
turn.text: Well, eventually.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: Yes, but I mean that's what you --

turn.speaker: charles_l_gilmore
turn.label: Mr. Charles L. Gilmore
turn.text: That's right.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: -- you sought.

turn.speaker: charles_l_gilmore
turn.label: Mr. Charles L. Gilmore
turn.text: That's right.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: And you've -- and you have said, I think, that you concede that the Bureau has jurisdiction of that kind of proceeding.

turn.speaker: charles_l_gilmore
turn.label: Mr. Charles L. Gilmore
turn.text: Yes, but that it --

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: But that they have not moved, you say because the Government has it moot?

turn.speaker: charles_l_gilmore
turn.label: Mr. Charles L. Gilmore
turn.text: Not a part of it.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: Is that right?

turn.speaker: charles_l_gilmore
turn.label: Mr. Charles L. Gilmore
turn.text: Not a part of it.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: But you deny that they have jurisdiction to initiate a contest proceeding for the purpose of deciding the validity of unpatented lands, is that it?

turn.speaker: charles_l_gilmore
turn.label: Mr. Charles L. Gilmore
turn.text: In this particular case, yes.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: charles_l_gilmore
turn.label: Mr. Charles L. Gilmore
turn.text: Because we don't -- there is no, I can make myself clear on that point.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: I wish you would because I don't quite understand, if I may just state what bothers me, Mr. Gilmore.

turn.speaker: charles_l_gilmore
turn.label: Mr. Charles L. Gilmore
turn.text: Well --

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: What it -- what you said to Mr. Justice Harlan was the mistake made by the Court of Appeals in saying that you'd made this concession before that court.

turn.speaker: charles_l_gilmore
turn.label: Mr. Charles L. Gilmore
turn.text: I said that they had the right to inquire into it because they had the right to inquire into it under our patent application.
But not to intervene in this particular condemnation suit, this is indifferent, entirely different proceeding.
In other words, they took possession of our land under their writ of possession on the 24th day of June, 1957.
Now, on the 18th day of April, the respondents here filed their proceeding in the District Court.

There was (Inaudible) -- they got a temporary restraining order to restrain the officials from proceeding any further with any contest because they had just filed a contest on -- I think, it was the 19th day of March of 1960.

So, they filed -- so when they filed that contest, then the proceeding before the Department -- before the courts had in existence for two years and eight months and we had been out of possession by the time that contest was filed.Most of these properties were under a hundred feet of water.
And by this time, around five or 600 feet of water, and we can't comply with the rule to proceed -- of evidence that's laid down on the Bureau of Land Management today.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: What is that --

turn.speaker: charles_l_gilmore
turn.label: Mr. Charles L. Gilmore
turn.text: We can't do it.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: What's that rule of evidence?

turn.speaker: charles_l_gilmore
turn.label: Mr. Charles L. Gilmore
turn.text: Because we can't go and point out our discovery points on each one of those claims, it's under a vast reservoir.
And if we can't point out our discovery point, we're out of the picture and they ruled it that way.

turn.speaker: john_m_harlan2
turn.label: Justice John M. Harlan
turn.text: Mr. Gilmore, supposing the Government had filed no contest at all and you got into trial in the District Court, and District Court said, “Well, so far as this mining claim is concerned, I'm going to withhold jurisdiction.
I'm going to send this, remit this under the doctrine of primary jurisdiction to the Department of Interior, the Land Division to get its expertise”.
Would the District Court have had power to do that?

turn.speaker: charles_l_gilmore
turn.label: Mr. Charles L. Gilmore
turn.text: Perhaps it had.
I've had that -- point I have never considered, Your Honor, (Voice Overlap) --

turn.speaker: john_m_harlan2
turn.label: Justice John M. Harlan
turn.text: Well, that's basic isn't it, that this issue were being concerned --

turn.speaker: charles_l_gilmore
turn.label: Mr. Charles L. Gilmore
turn.text: No.
What we're -- pardon me, Your Honor, but what -- but the -- that didn't -- that isn't the question.
That is -- I suppose, that would be within the general powers of the District Court.
I don't know, I wouldn't want to make that statement as to whether it is within the power or not.
Frankly, I just -- I don't know, we have a case similar and that's pending now on a petition for writ before this Court where that particular question is involved.

But if the Bureau of Land Management has had the opportunity over the period of years to institute its proceeding in -- to contest the validity of this claim, under these claims, and if they believe they had the right then why wait for two years and eight months after the federal court had been asked by the chief law officer of the Department of Interior to bring these proceedings in eminent domain.
Now, the chief law officer is the Solicitor for the Department, he has said in his letter to the United States Attorney General that the claims are invalid.
This whole case rests upon that statement, using that as the basis.
We are charged of withholding claims of -- that are invalid.
Property that belongs to the United States, properties to which we have no title, we've have never an opportunity yet to have the question of our title determined by anybody, anytime or any place.
It should be determined, I believe, in the District Court which was importuned in the first place by the Department.

If we go into a contest before the so-called hearing examiner system invoked under the Bureau of Land Management at the present time, the prosecuting attorney sitting right there is an Assistant Solicitor for the Department of the Interior.
That hearing examiner works under direct instructions from the Sec -- from the Solicitor for the Department.
Now, just what kind of opportunity do we have to present our case to an impartial tribunal?

turn.speaker: john_m_harlan2
turn.label: Justice John M. Harlan
turn.text: Oh, that's a different question because if you choose, if you don't get a fair hearing before the Department, you got a court review?

turn.speaker: charles_l_gilmore
turn.label: Mr. Charles L. Gilmore
turn.text: Yes, but the question is how far can the Court go on a review in such cases?
I don't know.
I have no -- we've never reached that far yet in the Department of the Interior with this present day set up.

Up until 1956, hearings were conducted by the register and receiver, later by the managers of the Land-Offices until the case of the O'Leary-Moore and then -- when this one, Secretary Seaton decided in that case in 1956 that there was no statute providing for hearings in mining location -- mining claim cases.
And therefore, the Department would have to comply with the Administrative Procedure Act but the Department has not complied with the Administrative Procedure Act.

Their appointment and their methods of handling cases to this hearing examiner system of their own does not comply with the Act because the hearing examiner is not an independent judge, if you put it that way, is not independent.
He's under the domination and under the direction, and under the control of the Solicitor for the Department of the Interior.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Mr. Gilmore, can you tell me approximately when these claims were staked out and when they were filed in the County Clerk's Office?

turn.speaker: charles_l_gilmore
turn.label: Mr. Charles L. Gilmore
turn.text: Well, as I say, there's some of them date far as back as in to the 90s, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Those that are involved in this particular case?

turn.speaker: charles_l_gilmore
turn.label: Mr. Charles L. Gilmore
turn.text: That's right.
Then the -- as I say, the -- for Your Honor's information, the -- we are only -- this is only one of five condemnation cases in which properties of this company are involved.

We have a lot of other properties in there because if there's a -- of the vast builders and all time hydraulic mining operation, where you put water up against the bank and wash her out and get the gold.

Purely a gold producing matter, we have alleged it in our complaint in the injunction suit that their valuable claims were -- they were being worked for their gold content and -- but we've had no -- we've got no -- nothing to reshoot that.

We still maintain that we have valid existing mining claims and on the decisions of this Court, they constitute grants from the United States and they can't be taken from us except by due process of law.

Now then, if have to go back into a hearing before the Bureau of Land Management, we are prohibited the right to have the question of compensation, determined by a jury and in -- so, in that respect we are denied due process of law.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Mr. Gilmore, one of -- this is a thing that's bothering me.
Suppose you had prevailed -- suppose you had a hearing before the Land Management Division or on your proceedings that you initiated in 1957 and the Government would just -- decided against you.
Would you be in any different position then than you would be in this case if the Land Management Division now decides against you?

turn.speaker: charles_l_gilmore
turn.label: Mr. Charles L. Gilmore
turn.text: Well, we would have had the right of review a long time ago.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Well, (Voice Overlap) --

turn.speaker: charles_l_gilmore
turn.label: Mr. Charles L. Gilmore
turn.text: We had our rights --

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Of course, that --

turn.speaker: charles_l_gilmore
turn.label: Mr. Charles L. Gilmore
turn.text: We would have had our rights determined.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: We can't wipe time out but it means --

turn.speaker: charles_l_gilmore
turn.label: Mr. Charles L. Gilmore
turn.text: But it --

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: -- so far as your rights and the value of your -- of whatever your property is.
Would you be in any different position than you are now?

turn.speaker: charles_l_gilmore
turn.label: Mr. Charles L. Gilmore
turn.text: Most assuredly, Your Honor.
Because at the present time we cannot go in there and prove we've got a dime's worth of value because we're under six or seven, or 5 or 600 feet of water.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Well, if they can't prove it before the Land Division, how can they prove it before the District Court?

turn.speaker: charles_l_gilmore
turn.label: Mr. Charles L. Gilmore
turn.text: Well, but we can prove -- we can have a different rule of evidence before the District Court in the condemnation suit because we can prove value as of the date of taking and this Court has decided that case.
That rule has the date of the taking on the 24th day of June 1957 but before the Department of the Interior, we can't put that sort of a rule into effect, they will not recognize it.
It will be as of the date of the hearing.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: But Mr. Gilmore, you still have to prove that something was taken, don't you?

turn.speaker: charles_l_gilmore
turn.label: Mr. Charles L. Gilmore
turn.text: Something was taken.
Certainly, it was taken.
Our property was taken.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: Well, I know but you have to prove that your property was taken.

turn.speaker: charles_l_gilmore
turn.label: Mr. Charles L. Gilmore
turn.text: We have (Voice Overlap) --

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: I gather the Chief Justice is asking, how are you in any different now in the District Court on truth then you would be before the Bureau?

turn.speaker: charles_l_gilmore
turn.label: Mr. Charles L. Gilmore
turn.text: We can prove by witnesses and by our records of location that we did have a location on that property and we maintain them throughout the years.
We paid tax.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: But you have to prove something more than that before the Bureau?

turn.speaker: charles_l_gilmore
turn.label: Mr. Charles L. Gilmore
turn.text: We have been taxed.
Yes, we would have to at the present time and before a hearing, before the Bureau of Land Management.
But we could prove at the time what we had in -- on the 24th day of June, 1957 in the condemnation hearing.
That would be the value at the time they took it but it --

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: Well --

turn.speaker: charles_l_gilmore
turn.label: Mr. Charles L. Gilmore
turn.text: -- under the Land Office hearing --

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: But that isn't the question, is it?
It is whether something was taken.
It's not what the value of what was taken.
It --

turn.speaker: charles_l_gilmore
turn.label: Mr. Charles L. Gilmore
turn.text: Well, they do (Voice Overlap) --

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: I don't gather -- I gather the Government --

turn.speaker: charles_l_gilmore
turn.label: Mr. Charles L. Gilmore
turn.text: They took the (Voice Overlap) --

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: -- doesn't concede that anything was taken.

turn.speaker: charles_l_gilmore
turn.label: Mr. Charles L. Gilmore
turn.text: They'd -- well, they've took our mining locations and they were grants from the United States.
I don't know.
It --

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: The question whether they are now -- and would you really have the same problem before the Bureau of Land Management in proving that you had a valid mining claim, as you would have in proving before the District Court that you had a valid mining claim?

turn.speaker: charles_l_gilmore
turn.label: Mr. Charles L. Gilmore
turn.text: No.
No, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Not the placement of value (Inaudible).

turn.speaker: charles_l_gilmore
turn.label: Mr. Charles L. Gilmore
turn.text: We had them -- but we can prove a valid mining claim under rules of evidence that would be recognizable in the courts as of the date of the taking.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: But why wouldn't you prove the same thing before the Bureau of Land Management?

turn.speaker: charles_l_gilmore
turn.label: Mr. Charles L. Gilmore
turn.text: We have different rules of evidence, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Well what is their rule of evidence?

turn.speaker: charles_l_gilmore
turn.label: Mr. Charles L. Gilmore
turn.text: As I explained, we have to prove, as of the date whenever we have that hearing.

Whenever we go to a hearing if we're required to go to a hearing, as of the date of that hearing then our right impinges upon that date as to whether at that time we had a discovery point we could show, we can't do it.
The one point alone would defeat our right.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: I have a -- I thought the Government's position was that the condemnation court in aiding it to determine whether anything was taken and the value of it would refer the matter to administrative agency.
The question that is certainly is referred is whether there -- anything was taken at the time it was -- that possession was ordered?

turn.speaker: charles_l_gilmore
turn.label: Mr. Charles L. Gilmore
turn.text: Well, I --

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: I'm not certain but (Voice Overlap)

turn.speaker: charles_l_gilmore
turn.label: Mr. Charles L. Gilmore
turn.text: I think Your Honor that we've -- we are thinking of two different things.
There's the difficulty as I -- as this Court has said of mining location, in mining location just the mining location itself as long as it is a subsisting matter of record.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Well, I've litigated for the Bureau of Land Management about several --

turn.speaker: charles_l_gilmore
turn.label: Mr. Charles L. Gilmore
turn.text: Well, it can involved difficulty and is getting tougher all the time, I ensure you.
The thing is that it is a grant, that mining claim is a grant.
We don't ever have to get a patent to it.
We don't have to do anything.
We'll mine it forever, as long as we want to.
We don't even have to mine it as long as we do the annual labor.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Assume you had a discovery --

turn.speaker: charles_l_gilmore
turn.label: Mr. Charles L. Gilmore
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: -- and they have mineral property, that's what exactly what the Government denied?

turn.speaker: charles_l_gilmore
turn.label: Mr. Charles L. Gilmore
turn.text: That's right, but the burden of proof is on us in the Bureau of Land Management.
According to them, we laid the -- they laid -- they laid down the rules of evidence but they're different in the rules that we have fight -- have to fight -- meet in the District Court.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: But what it -- that's what we're really been wondering but how are they really different?

turn.speaker: charles_l_gilmore
turn.label: Mr. Charles L. Gilmore
turn.text: The time in the first instance.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: I don't get that.

turn.speaker: charles_l_gilmore
turn.label: Mr. Charles L. Gilmore
turn.text: Well, the value, I think of the property taken is fixed as of the date of the taking.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Yes, but the Bureau won't get -- even get to the principal of value.

turn.speaker: charles_l_gilmore
turn.label: Mr. Charles L. Gilmore
turn.text: Well, I know but the value of it is based upon in a court, it would be.
But in the Bureau of Land Management the question is was there a discovery.
Well, we can't find out the discovery points, Your Honor, and therefore we don't have a discovery.
We lose on one point, we can't point it out.
We're under 600 feet of water.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Well, is that the same problem you have in the District Court?
They could (Voice Overlap) --

turn.speaker: charles_l_gilmore
turn.label: Mr. Charles L. Gilmore
turn.text: No --
-- no, no.
I will not have that at all.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: But by evidence in -- by evidence in the District Court, you could prove that you did have a discovery?

turn.speaker: charles_l_gilmore
turn.label: Mr. Charles L. Gilmore
turn.text: Absolutely.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: You say you could do that before the Bureau?

turn.speaker: charles_l_gilmore
turn.label: Mr. Charles L. Gilmore
turn.text: No, sir because they will not accept that proof.
They have a different rule, different settlements --

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: I suppose, Mr. Gilmore that you're right that on judicial review whether or not that rule is arbitrary and capricious under the circumstances that bother you would be before the District Court, wouldn't it?

turn.speaker: charles_l_gilmore
turn.label: Mr. Charles L. Gilmore
turn.text: Yes, but then that brings us right back to the another point your --

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: I must say to me it sounds pretty arbitrary and capricious to flood you with 600 feet of water.
And then say in consequence you can't prove a case, I can't read the view of it.

turn.speaker: charles_l_gilmore
turn.label: Mr. Charles L. Gilmore
turn.text: Well, I know but that un --

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: I hope not.

turn.speaker: charles_l_gilmore
turn.label: Mr. Charles L. Gilmore
turn.text: -- unfortunately that's the rule of evidence.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Well, is there any rule -- have you cited any authority for that Act in your brief that that is the rule that the --

turn.speaker: charles_l_gilmore
turn.label: Mr. Charles L. Gilmore
turn.text: No, it didn't -- I didn't think -- I didn't --

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: -- Bureau applies?

turn.speaker: charles_l_gilmore
turn.label: Mr. Charles L. Gilmore
turn.text: I didn't think that it was the time or place to do so.
I didn't think so.
The rule speaks for itself.
The decisions of the Department themselves speaks for itself -- themselves.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Well --

turn.speaker: charles_l_gilmore
turn.label: Mr. Charles L. Gilmore
turn.text: They say that you must prove the -- that if you lost your discovery point, you've lost your claim.
We're not concerned at the present time with the Bureau of Land Management is going to rule when it gets up there, or if it ever gets there.

The thing is if what we're trying to do at the present time is to determine which place has jurisdiction and administrative view or the federal court, the federal court being the one that was applied to first.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Is that your whole claim?
Are you directing only on the fact that they apply that in the courts first?

turn.speaker: charles_l_gilmore
turn.label: Mr. Charles L. Gilmore
turn.text: Yes, my -- that's not my whole -- (Voice Overlap) that's not -- that's not my whole case, no.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: What happens to you if this -- if the Court of Appeals' judgment is reversed?

turn.speaker: charles_l_gilmore
turn.label: Mr. Charles L. Gilmore
turn.text: We'll be right back in and the -- to the --

turn.speaker: tom_c_clark
turn.label: Justice Tom C. Clark
turn.text: Where are you?

turn.speaker: charles_l_gilmore
turn.label: Mr. Charles L. Gilmore
turn.text: We're lost.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Well, you've lost what though, what have you lost --

turn.speaker: charles_l_gilmore
turn.label: Mr. Charles L. Gilmore
turn.text: We've lost our mining claims because it will be utterly used -- it will be utterly used --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Or have you merely lost your right to have the validity of your claim determined in the courts first?

turn.speaker: charles_l_gilmore
turn.label: Mr. Charles L. Gilmore
turn.text: No.
But the Court wouldn't have right to do -- the Court will not determine the validity of the claims.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: But are you saying that the judgment here is reversed and if the judgment of the District Court is reins -- restored that you cannot still go into the Land Division and have this matter determined and then subject it to judicial review?
Or is it --

turn.speaker: charles_l_gilmore
turn.label: Mr. Charles L. Gilmore
turn.text: Oh, yes, that --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Is that what you are saying?

turn.speaker: charles_l_gilmore
turn.label: Mr. Charles L. Gilmore
turn.text: -- I can do that but I don't --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: What's that?

turn.speaker: charles_l_gilmore
turn.label: Mr. Charles L. Gilmore
turn.text: I don't see how you could --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: You'd have --

turn.speaker: charles_l_gilmore
turn.label: Mr. Charles L. Gilmore
turn.text: I don't think --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Do you think you can or cannot do that?

turn.speaker: charles_l_gilmore
turn.label: Mr. Charles L. Gilmore
turn.text: I don't think I can.
I don't see --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: You don't think its (Voice Overlap) --

turn.speaker: charles_l_gilmore
turn.label: Mr. Charles L. Gilmore
turn.text: I don't think I can.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: -- but you think the judgment cut you off from a --

turn.speaker: charles_l_gilmore
turn.label: Mr. Charles L. Gilmore
turn.text: I think --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: -- a hearing before the (Voice Overlap) --

turn.speaker: charles_l_gilmore
turn.label: Mr. Charles L. Gilmore
turn.text: I think the ruling of the Solicitor for the Department would cut us off.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Well, if -- you mean, cut you off from having it litigated there or try that?

turn.speaker: charles_l_gilmore
turn.label: Mr. Charles L. Gilmore
turn.text: No, it will cut -- he will (Voice Overlap) --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: But the thing is they'll decide against you.

turn.speaker: charles_l_gilmore
turn.label: Mr. Charles L. Gilmore
turn.text: No -- yes, they will because he's already decided against us Your Honor.
He's already decided the case against us.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Suppose they decide against you on a bad ground, what then?
On illegal ground, do you then -- do you think that you will have no right to have that reversed?

turn.speaker: charles_l_gilmore
turn.label: Mr. Charles L. Gilmore
turn.text: I can if he says that the land is not mineral in character and there has been no discovery, I -- would this -- I -- I'm not going to ask the court a question, (Inaudible) partly yes, I mean, and (Voice Overlap) --

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Mr. Gilmore, may I ask this question, could you and counsel give us a short memorandum on this question, what is it that you can prove to satisfy your claim in the District Court that you cannot use before the Bureau of Land Management.

turn.speaker: charles_l_gilmore
turn.label: Mr. Charles L. Gilmore
turn.text: I'll be glad to Your Honor.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: And further, what different rules of evidence are there in the Bureau and in the District Court on that question?

turn.speaker: charles_l_gilmore
turn.label: Mr. Charles L. Gilmore
turn.text: I will be glad to.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Would you in the -- in -- just a short memorandum.
I don't want you writing out a brief on it if necessary.

turn.speaker: charles_l_gilmore
turn.label: Mr. Charles L. Gilmore
turn.text: Your Honor could I have time enough, I'm a long way from home, in my office --

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Yes, you may.

turn.speaker: charles_l_gilmore
turn.label: Mr. Charles L. Gilmore
turn.text: And the --

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: You may take -- you may take the time that they reserved for.

turn.speaker: charles_l_gilmore
turn.label: Mr. Charles L. Gilmore
turn.text: Thank you very much.
